theoryTitle: Luffy vs Shanks Final Davy Back Fight
theoryText: The Davy Back Fight introduced in this arc will be used for the climactic confrontation between Luffy and Shanks. Rather than a traditional battle, they will compete in a Davy Back Fight to determine who is worthy of the One Piece, with the straw hat itself as the ultimate prize. This would fit One Piece's themes of friendly competition and allow them to test each other without killing intent.
author: Various One Piece theorists
evidenceFor: Oda rarely introduces concepts without future payoff
The Davy Back Fight allows competitive confrontation without death
Shanks giving Luffy the straw hat creates a perfect symbolic prize
Would maintain the series' tone while providing climactic tension
Recent revelations about Rocks D. Xebec using Davy Back Fights adds credibility
evidenceAgainst: The arc is often considered filler-like by fans
Luffy and Shanks' relationship may require a different resolution
The theory relies on Oda planning this from the Long Ring Long Land arc
relatedTheories: Long Ring Long Land as crucial foreshadowing
discussionTopics: The symbolism of the straw hat as a prize
How a Davy Back Fight could serve as the series climax
Parallels between Foxy's 920 wins and future legendary Davy Back Fights

theoryTitle: Long Ring Long Land as Hidden Foreshadowing
theoryText: Despite being dismissed as one of One Piece's weakest arcs, Long Ring Long Land actually contains crucial foreshadowing for the series' endgame. The introduction of Davy Back Fights is Oda's way of planting seeds for major future plot points, similar to how Rocks D. Xebec was later revealed to have used this tradition to build his legendary crew. The arc's seeming inconsequence is intentional misdirection.
author: One Piece community theorists
evidenceFor: Rocks D. Xebec using Davy Back Fights was revealed in later chapters, validating the concept's importance
Oda is known for long-term foreshadowing spanning hundreds of chapters
The arc's unusual tone and structure may be deliberate misdirection
19 chapters/13 episodes is significant investment for a 'pointless' arc
Recent story developments have renewed interest in Davy Back Fights
evidenceAgainst: Could simply be a fun diversion arc without deeper meaning
Not all One Piece content needs to serve endgame purposes
relatedTheories: Davy Back Fight will return in final saga
Elbaf arc connection to Davy Back Fights
discussionTopics: The purpose of seemingly minor arcs
How Rocks D. Xebec revelation changed perception of this arc

theoryTitle: Davy Back Fight Origins on Pirate Island
theoryText: The Davy Back Fight tradition originated on the legendary Pirate Island (Hachinosu/Fullalead) and was used by some of the world's most powerful pirates, including Rocks D. Xebec. The introduction of this concept in Episode 208 is actually introducing a major element of world history that will be explored when the Straw Hats reach endgame locations and confront the series' final mysteries.
author: One Piece lore theorists
evidenceFor: Later manga chapters confirm Rocks D. Xebec used Davy Back Fights
The tradition is stated to originate from Pirate Island
The formal rules and ceremonies suggest ancient, significant origins
The Three Articles have the weight of sacred pirate law
Connection to major historical figures validates the tradition's importance
evidenceAgainst: Foxy's use of it seems relatively frivolous compared to its legendary origins
relatedTheories: Pirate Island's role in One Piece history
discussionTopics: How legendary pirates used Davy Back Fights differently than Foxy
The true significance of the Three Articles
Whether other major crews were formed through these contests

theoryTitle: Foxy's 920 Wins Parallel to Historical Significance
theoryText: Foxy's 920-win streak, while impressive, is meant to pale in comparison to the historical Davy Back Fights conducted by legends like Rocks D. Xebec. This sets up a contrast between someone exploiting the tradition for easy wins (Foxy) versus those who used it to gather the strongest warriors (Rocks). The arc shows both the potential and the corruption of pirate traditions.
author: One Piece analysis community
evidenceFor: The contrast between Foxy's cheating and the tradition's sacred nature
Rocks D. Xebec's legendary crew vs Foxy's 500+ random members
The arc demonstrates both proper and improper uses of the tradition
Foxy wins through cunning rather than strength, unlike historical users
evidenceAgainst: May be reading too deeply into what's meant to be a comedic arc
Foxy's characterization may not be meant to contrast with Rocks
relatedTheories: Quality vs quantity in crew building
discussionTopics: How Foxy represents exploitation of traditions
